title: Searching for Meaning in the Life of Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf: A Call to Meaningful Responses to Tragedies - PMC

Frankl argues that power is not an end but a means to pursue meaning (Barnes, 2000 ; Frankl, 1985a , b ; 2006 ; 2014).

Frankl argues that power is not an end but a means to pursue meaning (Barnes, 2000 ; Frankl, 1985a , b ; 2006 ; 2014).
She wrote: “If I wanted to be successful according to the terms of success that had long dominated our society, was to go with the flow. But I could not do that” (Johnson-Sirleaf, 2010 , p. 67).

Another instance which shows her will to meaning is in her career choices. She held several positions in prestigious organisations (e.g., the U.N. and World Bank). She could have enjoyed a luxurious life away from her country’s oppression and civil war in such posts. However, she still decided to relocate to Liberia and, in 1997 ran for the presidency against a warlord, Charles Taylor (Johnson-Sirleaf, 2010).

Another instance which shows her will to meaning is in her career choices. She held several positions in prestigious organisations (e.g., the U.N. and World Bank). She could have enjoyed a luxurious life away from her country’s oppression and civil war in such posts. However, she still decided to relocate to Liberia and, in 1997 ran for the presidency against a warlord, Charles Taylor (Johnson-Sirleaf, 2010).
This may suggest that she sought a more meaningful career than a well-paying, meaningless profession (Barnes, 2000 ; Fabry, 2021 ; Frankl, 2012).
This may suggest that she sought a more meaningful career than a well-paying, meaningless profession (Barnes, 2000 ; Fabry, 2021 ; Frankl, 2012).
This may suggest that she sought a more meaningful career than a well-paying, meaningless profession (Barnes, 2000 ; Fabry, 2021 ; Frankl, 2012).
Johnson-Sirleaf seemed to have served others with faith and demonstrated selfless leadership for the greater good (Wong et al., 2022).
Johnson-Sirleaf had short-term tasks such as gaining corporate world experience and challenging the warlords and status quo (including the ideology of patriarchy) (Johnson-Sirleaf, 2010).
However, she did not accept the tasks as they would not have fulfilled her, as they contradicted her beliefs and were not self-chosen (Fabry, 2021 ; Marshall & Marshall, 2012).
